Context:
Program Name: Practical Nursing
Code: S121
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: January, May, September
Domestic Tuition: $5,204.00 *
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Clinical Placement
Program Description: The Practical Nursing program teaches students the foundational skills required to work as a registered practical nurse in Ontario. Following successful completion of this program, graduates will be eligible to write the RPN Registration Examinations.
Class Schedule:Classes are held at the Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences located at the Waterfront Campus and are scheduled between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. from Monday to Friday.
Clinical Placement: Clinical placement experiences are conducted under direct faculty supervision within varied patient care settings across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Practical Nursing program at George Brown College is approved by the College of Nurses of Ontario (www.cno.org). Students participate in placements across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) under faculty supervision, which may include extended shifts with evening and weekend hours. The program covers nursing, health assessment, human anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology, and the humanities. George Brown's Practical Nursing students learn and practice skills at the accredited Simulation Centre, which spans nearly 24,000 square feet. Off-site clinical experience is also provided with valued partners. Graduates who pass the qualifying examinations are eligible to apply for registration as a Registered Practical Nurse (RPN) in Ontario.

Public Health recommends that people working with vulnerable communities be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, and clinical agency partners require students to be fully vaccinated for clinical placements. Students who are not vaccinated risk not being able to complete their clinical placement course requirements.

George Brown College Practical Nursing program graduates have scored near or above the provincial average on regulatory exams for the past three years (College of Nurses of Ontario, Nursing Registration Exams Report 2021 [cno.org]). Some students may be required to enroll in courses aimed at enhancing profession-based written and verbal English language skills based on mandatory placement testing.

The College of Nurses of Ontario approves the Practical Nursing program at George Brown College (College of Nurses of Ontario – Approved [1]).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The George Brown Practical Nursing Program offers hands-on learning through a nearly 24,000 square foot Simulation Centre and off-site clinical experience with valued partners. Students may participate in clinical placements within various patient care settings across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), including acute care hospitals, rehabilitation centres, and long-term care facilities. The final semester of the program involves a clinical practicum experience under faculty supervision and with a preceptor.

Graduates of the Practical Nursing program can find employment in practice settings such as acute and community care hospitals, long-term care, rehabilitation, and other health-care facilities or organizations requiring nursing knowledge and expertise. Students who complete the George Brown Practical Nursing program or a two-year community college PN program in Ontario with a minimum cumulative average of 75% and not less than 70% in any element may be eligible to study the R.P.N. Bridge to B.Sc.N. Pathway at Trent University's Nursing degree program offered on-site at George Brown College.

Additionally, graduates with an interest in working in long-term care facilities can apply for the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care postgraduate certificate (S417). This two-semester program is delivered online and on-demand to accommodate working professionals and includes a clinical field placement component.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides a list of courses offered during Semesters 1 to 4 in the Practical Nursing program at the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing. The courses are primarily identified by their codes and names, with some exceptions such as "COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts" and "GNED: General Education Elective". Here is a list of the courses mentioned in each semester:

Semester 1:
- ANAT 1052: Anatomy and Physiology for Practical Nursing I
- NURS 1067: Foundations of Nursing Theory
- NURS 1098: The PN Role & Interprofessional Relationships
- NURS 1100: Foundations in Clinical Practice (Lab)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- PHAR 1055: Foundations in Pharmacology and Calculations for PN
- GNED: General Education Elective
- GSSC 1057: Lifespan Development

Semester 2:
- ANAT 1053: Anatomy and Physiology for Practical Nursing II
- PATH 1016: Pathology and Therapeutics I
- NURS 1027: Nursing Theory for Practical Nurses I
- PHAR 1057: Pharmacology for Practical Nurses I
- NURS 1068: Health Assessment in Clinical Practice I
- NURS 1104: Nursing Lab Skills II
- NURS 1105: Clinical Practicum

Semester 3:
- PATH 1017: Pathology and Therapeutics II
- NURS 1028: Nursing Theory for Practical Nurses II
- PHAR 1059: Pharmacology for Practical Nurses II
- NURS 2018: Clinical Applications III
- NURS 2016: Profession of Nursing II
- NURS 2023: Health Assessment in Clinical Practice II
- NURS 2028: Nursing Lab Skills III
- COMM 1147: Critical Enquiry in Practical Nursing I

Semester 4:
- NURS 2017: Nursing Theory for Practical Nurses III
- NURS 2020: Clinical Applications IV
- NURS 2029: Sociological Perspectives in Nursing
- GNED: General Education Elective

The text also mentions that the course offerings are subject to change due to ongoing program review and improvements to meet the College of Nurses of Ontario entry-to-practice requirements. This information is important for prospective students to be aware of, as they may need to check the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing webpage and/or receive correspondence prior to starting or returning for updated course information.

Context:
The text provides information on the nursing program offered at George Brown College, including the following key points:

1. The nursing program involves communicating therapeutically with clients and members of the healthcare team, assessing clients across the lifespan, planning safe and competent nursing care, selecting and performing nursing interventions, evaluating outcomes, acting equitably and justly, adapting to various healthcare settings, and contributing to creating a healthy and safe work environment.
2. The tuition for the first two semesters of the program is $5,204.00 for domestic students, with additional costs subject to change. International students are not accepted into this program.
3. Financial assistance in the form of OSAP funding is available for eligible applicants.
4. Admission requirements include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grades 12 English and Mathematics with a grade of 70% or higher (or grade 11 Biology with a grade of 70% or higher), and meeting other selection criteria as outlined by the college.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* The Practical Nursing program at the college requires applicants to have a grade of 70% or higher in Biology and Chemistry, either in grade 11 or 12.
* Interviews are by invitation only for qualified applicants to assess specific competencies related to the field of Nursing.
* Mature students (19 years old or older without an OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment or consider upgrading to achieve credits needed in English, Math, Chemistry, or Biology.
* Applicants with existing post-secondary nursing education from Canadian or international institutions are required to submit all transcripts.
* Transfer credit and course exemptions for related nursing courses will be decided on a case-by-case basis by the School of Nursing.
* Qualified applicants from the A109 Pre-Health Sciences program may be invited for an online video interview.
* Only the most qualified applicants will be offered an opportunity to interview, and only the top-ranked applicants will be offered a seat in the program.
* Applications are considered only for the first semester of the Practical Nursing program.
* The program is delivered in a 2-1-2 format with two consecutive semesters, one semester as a break, and the final two consecutive semesters.
* Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits, and more information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
* Clinical Pre-placement Health Form requirements and program policies apply upon acceptance into the program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Students in this program are required to meet and complete various pre-placement requirements within 10 to 12 weeks of acceptance. These requirements include providing proof of medical records such as TDAP shot, COVID-19, MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, Two-Step TB Skin Test, a clear Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year, a Standard First Aid Certificate renewed every three years, and a Basic Life Support certificate renewed every year. Students must also get an annual flu shot and mask fit test renewed every two years.

Students are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 for clinical placements, as required by public health and clinical agency partners. The Vulnerable Sector Check, which is a background check required for students entering field or clinical placement, must be completed and renewed every year before the placement begins. The process typically takes two to three months but can take up to eight months under certain circumstances.

All costs associated with these health requirements are the responsibility of the student. To download the mandatory Pre-placement health form and for more details, students should visit the Clinical Pre-placement website.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Practical Nursing Program (PN) S121 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Students are required to obtain a Vulnerable Sector Check to participate in field or clinical placements at the college. Those unable to provide a "clear" Vulnerable Sector Check will not be able to start their placement and complete the program, potentially jeopardizing their progress. The fees for the vulnerable sector check vary and must be paid by the student. Students should apply for domestic admission through Ontario Colleges.

- Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing: phone - 416-415-5000, ext. 2367, email - nursing@georgebrown.ca, office hours - Monday to Thursday, 8 a.m. – 4:30 p.m., Friday, 8 a.m. – 4 p.m.
- Alternatively, visit the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing on the seventh floor of the Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences at the Waterfront Campus.
- Contact Centre: phone - 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559), long distance 1-800-265-2002.
